body: It looks like we forgot to update the docs back when we did that change. We only updated examples to reflect the changes for some reason.
OK, I am going to revert the code changes and just updating the doc
Updating the docs sounds like a reasonable thing to do. My bad for missing that in the first place.

@nishantmonu51 My comments about "doing it before the persist" were basically saying that it looks like we are making changes so that the read side of IncrementalIndex handles things "correctly".  It seems like there is also potential for fixing it on the "write" side, i.e. when the event is initially put into the IncrementalIndex.

I haven't dug that deep into the changes to have a specific suggestion that I'm offering though, was just a thought as I read through your changes.

@drcrallen That seems like a legitimate way to communicate things to the various nodes.  That said, I still think that this decision deserves to be called out on the developer list rather than hidden inside this pull request.

A choice and agreement should be reached about how we handle this sort of communication.  It's very possible that agreement is reached and we keep going with how you have implemented it here until we do the larger, more involved change.  But, this is something that should be raised up as a larger conversation.
@davrodpin did you get a chance to make the proposed changes?

@fjy, @xvrl, @drcrallen, I've added the container name to the load spec. and also made the Azure connector (AzureStorage) to be able to use different containers if necessary (thinking about moving and archiving segments here).

Hi Fangjin,

First of all, thanks for the answer, I realize indeed we might have issues in our usage of Druid but still, aren't realtime nodes supposed to ingest data in realtime and answer clients' queries ? Because here this design is not respected and there is absolutely no logic behind throttling ingestion to the point of DISABLING ingestion completely on a group of kafka partitions.

I still feel there is a serious design problem in the way Druid ingests its data through Kafka:
if the ingestion is being throttled to save the node from crashing, why even claim ownership over partitions other nodes could trivially read from ? It only blocks other consumers from reading data they could ingest, triggering latency issues and ultimately forcing us to reindex data at a later point (meaning realtime data becomes incorrect, incomplete).

Thanks for addressing this issue, I'm sure you can see this is not a behaviour that can be acceptable.

And if you still think this is a correct behavior and you feel throttling ingestion is the way to go, then I suggest to throttle the whole process, not just the reading part but also the Kafka rebalancing part, that way, nodes not restarted have a chance to continue ingesting data while late nodes can catch up with their handing off process.

Thanks!

Oh, I think I've been misunderstood a bit here. The issue is still here. Hint from @drcrallen made it a bit less frequent, but I can still reproduce it without much problem in our dev environment. The "closed" part was only related to the question about intermediatePersist behaviour.

BTW: Apparently I cannot reopen issues if closed by someone else, @xvrl :-(.
@nishantmonu51 the j8 travis failure seems to be transient. Can you double check that?
closing and reopening to trigger rebuild
Not an issue, If the middlemanager is provisioning nodes, it waits for that to finish before updating the configs.
closing as it is dupe of #709
is it possible to add a test for this?
After discussing with @xvrl  I think a better solution will be incoming very shortly...
hmmm... other unit tests failing, closing until resolved

Yeah, the unit tests are not at all friendly to this change. Leaving closed since it seems to change prior behavior too much.

Opening issue instead.

This is not as needed as I expected because LoadSpec can fetch the segments regardless of where they are located. So there is a workarround, and since this adds some complexity I'm closing for now unless someone really wants this capacity.
@T0aD, I think it makes sense to delay claiming partitions until the realtime node is finished starting up and ready to ingest. The linked PR makes that change.
Waow ! Great news, can't wait to test it, thanks a bunch @gianm !
Add test for cleanup method.
failed with java8, looking
do the links still work?
@davrodpin do you mind squashing commits before we merge?
@fjy, @xvrl: squashed it is!
@fjy is there an easy way to test? and do you see a reason for changed links to not  work?

@himanshug, @fjy while we are at it, should we make all our links lowercase? When testing on OS X or Windows, someone would not be able to see whether a link is broken because those filesystems are case-insensitive, whereas GitHub Pages is case-sensitive.
fixes #1053
@xvrl lowercasing makes sense, I will update the PR. @fjy let us know if you think otherwise.

@himanshug If you issue install the ruby gem jekyll and issue 'jekyll -w serve' in the docs directory, you should be able to load up the docs locally and view them in a web browser. Can you verify the links still work? My concern is that links on the internet may reference the latest docs and use the mixed case tutorial links.

Unless we don't change the file names at all we'll have broken links on the Internet. Hence my suggestion to take advantage of this change to make it lowercase. 

I've spend a fair amount of time cleaning up casing problems in links in the past, so I say we just bite the bullet.

Our documentation will not always have the same set of pages, and the best way around that is to provide permanent redirects for some time so search engines can update their index.

our doc links are versioned, so,
http://druid.io/docs/0.7.1.1/Tutorial:-A-First-Look-at-Druid.html
will be valid even after changes we make to the names

however, I understand that  "http://druid.io/docs/latest/Tutorial:-A-First-Look-at-Druid.html" will break (and will show the page with link to druid.io) and if we think that this is big enough of a problem then redirection is the only solution.

I am not entirely familiar with the current doc publishing setup. Is "redirection" a matter of creating a file somewhere containing lines "from -> to" or is it something more?
@himanshug you can see an example of redirection here https://github.com/druid-io/druid-io.github.io/blob/master/api/0.6.173/index.md
@fjy so, lowecase + setup redirects sounds ok?
@janakg Did you get a chance to update this PR? I think creating a new doc titled "Integrating Druid with Other Technologies" under the Development section would be a good place for this image
@fjy @pjain1 should be in our corp CLA. Please let me know if he is not there already.
@xvrl can you check the corp CLA?
:+1:  Can you squash the commits and I can merge
@fjy Sure, I will get some time in next week, will create a new page and submit it.
Done.
I think it's good to add these links back.  I was just looking today at what granularities are available, and I think five_minute is also possible.
@xvrl @fjy ok, changed filenames to just contain lowercase and dashes, updated all the links. Tested the links and they are working fine.

@xvrl trying to setup redirection on https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1344/files#diff-0cea66d55e30b21d83fbba081157afa1 but it does not work locally when I do "jekyll serve". Does this look OK to you?

@himanshug it looks like the redirection is working for the page you changed. The problem I am seeing is that when checking out the repository on a case-insensitive filesystem, you can only edit one of the files, and I'm not sure which one will prevail. I guess that means we need to change more than just the casing for things to be editable on Windows an OS X.

Btw, in order to test the redirection, you need to install the `jekyll-redirect-from` package using `gem install [--user-install] 'jekyll-redirect-from'` and also add the following snippet to `druid/docs/_config.yml`, which I haven't copied over from the main druid website repository.

``` yaml
gems:
  - jekyll-redirect-from
```
@himanshug alternatively, we can also organize the code into sub-directories to structure it a little bit better. I know @fjy might have some suggestions.

@sixtus, @fjy, how do you feel about instead just skipping null messages in the kafka firehose, or counting them as unparseable?

The reason is that skipping past any errors on getSink/sink.add seems like a heavy handed way of dealing with the problem. There might be other errors that occur that we don't want to skip past.
@gianm I like that solution. Counting them as unparseable seems pretty reasonable.

Results from bigger row sizes shows compression overheads - 

```
Benchmark                           (bytes)  (valuesPerRowBound)  Mode  Cnt       Score       Error  Units
VSizeIndexedBenchmark.compressed          1                  100  avgt   20   25689.728    415.770  us/op
VSizeIndexedBenchmark.compressed          1                 1000  avgt   20  243519.240   4682.752  us/op
VSizeIndexedBenchmark.compressed          2                  100  avgt   20   26316.588    410.648  us/op
VSizeIndexedBenchmark.compressed          2                 1000  avgt   20  250558.075   4187.638  us/op
VSizeIndexedBenchmark.compressed          3                  100  avgt   20   27874.297    443.335  us/op
VSizeIndexedBenchmark.compressed          3                 1000  avgt   20  261986.150   5688.185  us/op
VSizeIndexedBenchmark.compressed          4                  100  avgt   20   27519.709    635.537  us/op
VSizeIndexedBenchmark.compressed          4                 1000  avgt   20  261203.560  12649.479  us/op
```

```
VSizeIndexedBenchmark.uncompressed        1                  100  avgt   20   19293.312    519.829  us/op
VSizeIndexedBenchmark.uncompressed        1                 1000  avgt   20  238587.613   7246.682  us/op
VSizeIndexedBenchmark.uncompressed        2                  100  avgt   20   18911.993    233.938  us/op
VSizeIndexedBenchmark.uncompressed        2                 1000  avgt   20  238703.940   6779.125  us/op
VSizeIndexedBenchmark.uncompressed        3                  100  avgt   20   19002.343    198.896  us/op
VSizeIndexedBenchmark.uncompressed        3                 1000  avgt   20  173601.575   2931.477  us/op
VSizeIndexedBenchmark.uncompressed        4                  100  avgt   20   18916.626    233.390  us/op
VSizeIndexedBenchmark.uncompressed        4                 1000  avgt   20  233899.600   3237.456  us/op
```

I mostly thrown this up to raise awareness that it's trivial to nuke realtime intake via input data. It's not the nicest patch, but hey, production was down and my backlog is more than full atm.

While skipping the null msgs in the firehose certainly is an option, not catching all possible exceptions in the intake is just asking for the next issue to nuke realtime.

So in short: both is probably the best solution.

Overall I'm :+1:  here. The approach of splitting out the offsets and values into two compressed sub-indices looks good and should fit in fine with the normal access patterns. The drastic jump in error bounds for the largest compressions are a bit concerning, but microbenchmarks in this case may not be indicative of actual query performance and query results would be very handy for comparison. Additionally, this may affect over-committed historical nodes (more disk than memory) drastically differently than under-committed historical nodes (more memory than disk) when swapping in pages from disk, which is much more difficult to test. I would expect the query results to favor this PR in the case where there is much more disk than ram.
@himanshug should we also add `doubleMin` and `doubleMax` for consistency with the `sum` aggregators?
@xvrl yes, will add the doubleMax/doubleMin types also and update document with same. But, in the code, we will still support max/min types for backward compatibility.

thank you @rayrapetyan, we don't currently run or test on OpenJDK, and we only have limited experience with it. It seems OpenJDK does not include a javascript engine by default like Oracle JDK does. Glad to know it works with OpenJDK 8 though.

@himanshug backwards compatibility is required for rolling upgrades.
If we don't want to go through the trouble of supporting both, we should leave things as is.
@xvrl , let us keep the max/min as is. this PR is ready to be merged then.

It's unclear which version of Jackson would work for everyone. Different distributions probably rely on different version of Jackson, so it might not be possible to find one that works for everyone. As far as I know, stock Hadoop does not depend on com.fasterxml jackson, only the old org.codehaus version, so this seems to be a distribution specific problem.

Instead of downgrading, it might be more useful to provide build profiles for specific versions of hadoop that include the right version of Jackson, similar to what do Apache Spark does.
just a data point, jackson-2.4.x works fine for me with hadoop-2.6
@himanshug are you using stock Apache Hadoop or something else?
@xvrl We have a major hadoop team internally managing a version of hadoop  which is more or less same as apache but might have a few customizations on top.

@himanshug,  regarding supporting have both "max" and "doubleMax", I wonder why the json mapping code you mentioned dint worked, we did exactly similar changes for ConvertSegmentTask which is mapped to two names version_converter and convert_segment. 
Can you check again what went wrong in your case ?

@nishantmonu51 i don't think it works for ConvertSegmentTask either. Have you tried deserializing with type=convert_segment.
see the ut in  #1358

@himanshug @drcrallen one way to handle aliases would be to create a jackson mixin with the old name for the class in question. It would not convert from the old name to the new name on serialization, but I think that's acceptable.
@xvrl https://github.com/himanshug/druid/commit/bf5c784c45749b5d7a06150169eb558750cd2184 is one way of setting up alias that is working fine. how does that look?
https://github.com/himanshug/druid/commit/bf5c784c45749b5d7a06150169eb558750cd2184 is one way of setting up alias that is working fine. how does that look?

Just wondering, but did we explore chunking up the compressed buffers to be first the offsets and then the values and then just store one un-compressed index of row offsets to compressed buffers?

My thinking is that co-locating might result in improved CPU cache utilization and wondering if this was explored at all.

@nishantmonu51 sure, I can rename all the Max/Min*.java to [DoubleMax/DoubleMin]*.java
and have [Max/Min]AggregatorFacorty extend [DoubleMax/DoubleMin]AggregatorFactory
is that what you meant to say?

also, I'm waiting for @xvrl to confirm if this looks right approach to him overall.
yeah, thats what i meant :)
@fjy any thoughts on whether to prepend all filenames with something like "docs-" or move stuff around to other folders?

No, i havn't explored that path. I initially thought of storing all the offsets and then the values in single flat buffer and compress that in chunks, the problem with that approach was the access pattern, for row access it was first uncompressing and loading the chunk containing offsets and then the one containing values unloading the offset buffer again, also i found it simpler to have two separate buffers for offsets and values.

@himanshug im not sure the value add of having "docs-" appended to everything as all the files are already in a docs directory. I think having subdirectories that match the headings of the TOC would be useful to organize files. We can also have a subdirectory for "unused"/"legacy" or something.

If I'm understanding this correctly, this looks like a way to run a conversion task over Hadoop MR.  That is, logically, it is executing tasks using Hadoop MR (and ultimately YARN) as the task manager instead of using whatever the Indexing Service is using.

I'm not against this, but I also kinda wonder if we shouldn't make a generic "run tasks on hadoop" job and then have the conversion task be a part of that?

@cheddar : Yes, that is a longer goal.  Some of the aspects of this PR will be combined with the hadoop task once this has proven stable. A future goal would be to make a better task container that can run on the indexing service, yarn, or mesos.

Yeah, storing the whole thing in one buffer is definitely not good.

If there are performance tests in place, it might not be too difficult to try implementing it where the lengths and the values are combined into individual buffers and see if that has any effect.  Also might not be worth it.  Either way, compressing multi-valued columns is a win, so we should enable it ;).

Hrm, fwiw, I also think this should be handled by the catch statements in the FireChief instead of inside the plumber itself.

I also agree with doing both.  We should have a big noisy catch all that screams really loudly and then also add protection from the specific issue that Hagen ran into.

@cheddar I think that makes sense. It would be useful to have more column introspection capabilities at the query engine / aggregator level, either for optimization purposes or to provide more flexible implementations. Maybe this could also be used to better formalize what the aggregator "types" mean and move in the direction of having columns other than strings be used as dimensions.

In the meantime I think we should just add `longMax/longMin`, `doubleMax/doubleMin`, provide backwards compatibility for seamless upgrade purposes, and deprecate the current behavior of `min/max` to indicate it will change in a future version and may not always return double at some point.
@himanshug sounds good to me to do the aliasing using the subclass, let's just make sure to have serde tests for it.

@xvrl @nishantmonu51  I think, all the review comments are taken care of. We have both min/max and doubleMin/doubleMax with backward compatibility.
All the [Max/Min]*.java have been renamed to [DoubleMax/DoubleMin]*.java
We can remove [Max/Min]AggregatorFactory.java when backward compatibility is no longer needed
Added more UTs for Double[Max/Min] aggregation as well.

@cheddar we can add the JMH tests we wrote for the compression stuff as a sub-project. If you or someone else would like to experiment with different column layouts. It might make sense to add those anyway to start a proper micro-benchmark suite that could help us optimize key parts of Druid.

@xvrl @cheddar introspection in general sounds like a good idea. but please note that if we make max/min intelligent and return appropriate aggregator based on the stored column type then technically it will not be "backward compatible" as in the old world max/min on long columns would've returned double result. We might be fine with that but just putting it here.

@himanshug the `content` folder does not actually exist in the github-pages repository where thing get published, so someone checking out the druid-io.github.io repository would have issues with the names conflicting. I agree with @fjy that following the TOC layout makes sense.
@himanshug I think we are in agreement. My last comment noted that we would deprecate the behavior, not the actual api itself, so someone expecting double should move to using doubleXXX
@anwenxu Can we get a description of the changes?
@anwenxu I don't think these changes compile.
@xvrl rebased for clean commit history. ready to merge.
sure, will put those in folders as they are bucketed in toc.
This sounds different from, but related to, #784. Both are races but in different directions.

@xvrl, just wondering are there any issues with adding test dependencies for jmh libraries and add benchmark tests along with the existing caliper benchmarks, benchmark tests will follow the same convention as caliper tests i.e will be named as *Benchmark.java ?

The existing conversion tasks is also not standalone, so I don't see why this one would need to be.

It would also greatly simplify this PR to remove all metadata rated stuff, since that's unrelated to the task itself if we remove the standalone option.

@rayrapetyan given that openjdk 7 doesn't provide a javascript scriptengine, I think we should simply document that when running OpenJDK, at least version 8 is required, but that we have not tested this extensively.
